sections.content: Most people spend more time planning vacations than planning careers. A strategic approach to career development dramatically increases earning potential, job satisfaction, and long-term success. Career planning isn't about rigidly following a script—it's about understanding your goals, the market landscape, and making intentional choices that compound over time.

sections.title: Assessing Your Starting Point
items: Skills inventory: List technical and soft skills you've developed (programming, writing, public speaking, project management)
Values clarification: What matters most? Money, work-life balance, impact, creativity, autonomy, prestige?
Strengths identification: What do you do better than most? What energizes you?
Market position: How does your compensation compare to market rates? Use Levels.fyi, Glassdoor, PayScale
Growth trajectory: Are you learning and advancing, or stagnating?

sections.content: Career capital is your accumulation of rare and valuable skills. Early career (0-5 years), prioritize learning over earning. Take positions that teach you valuable skills, even if they pay less initially. By mid-career (5-15 years), you should be converting that capital into higher compensation, leadership roles, or entrepreneurial ventures.

sections.title: Creating Your Career Vision
items: 5-year horizon: What role, salary, skills, lifestyle do you want?
Work backwards: What positions lead to your target? What skills are required?
Multiple paths: Identify 2-3 viable routes (corporate track, entrepreneurship, consulting)
Decision filters: Create rules for evaluating opportunities (must offer X skill development, minimum Y salary)
Review quarterly: Adjust based on changing circumstances and new information

sections.title: Career Planning Mistakes
items: Following default path: Taking promotions or jobs because 'that's next' without evaluating fit
Optimizing for wrong variable: Chasing prestige or comfort over skill development and growth
Golden handcuffs: Staying in comfortable but limiting roles for incremental raises
No skill differentiation: Being generically good at many things instead of excellent at valuable things
Ignoring market trends: Building skills in declining industries or obsolete technologies

sections.content: Your career strategy should balance exploitation (maximizing current position) and exploration (developing new skills and opportunities). Too much exploitation leads to stagnation; too much exploration prevents capitalizing on accumulated career capital. The ratio shifts over time: explore aggressively early, exploit strategically later.

quiz.question: What should be prioritized in early career (0-5 years)?
quiz.explanation: Early career should prioritize learning and developing rare, valuable skills over maximizing immediate compensation. This builds career capital.

quiz.question: What is career capital?
options: Accumulation of rare and valuable skills
quiz.explanation: Career capital is your accumulation of rare and valuable skills that give you leverage and options in the job market.

sections.content: Your personal brand is your professional reputation—what people think of when they hear your name. In a connected world, your brand precedes you into every interview, negotiation, and opportunity. A strong personal brand opens doors, commands higher compensation, and creates opportunities others don't see. You're building a brand whether intentionally or not—might as well be strategic.

sections.title: Components of Personal Brand
items: Expertise: What are you known for? What value do you uniquely provide?
Visibility: Do the right people know you exist and what you can do?
Credibility: Can you deliver on promises? Do you have proof of results?
Consistency: Does your message and presentation align across platforms?
Authenticity: Are you genuine or playing a character? People detect fakeness

sections.content: Choose a positioning that's both valuable and authentic. 'Marketing specialist' is generic. 'B2B SaaS growth marketer specializing in product-led growth' is specific and valuable. Riches are in niches—being known as the go-to person for something specific is more valuable than being somewhat known for everything.

sections.title: Building Brand Visibility
items: LinkedIn optimization: Professional photo, compelling headline, detailed experience, regular posts about your expertise
Content creation: Write articles, record videos, share insights about your field 2-3x weekly
Speaking engagements: Present at conferences, meetups, webinars in your industry
Open source contributions: For developers, contribute to projects and share your work
Help publicly: Answer questions in forums, Slack communities, Reddit in your field
Consistency: Small regular contributions beat occasional bursts

sections.title: LinkedIn Strategy
items: Headline: Not job title—value proposition (e.g., 'I help SaaS companies reduce churn through data-driven CX')
About section: Tell your story, highlight achievements, include keywords, add contact info
Experience: Use bullet points showing impact with numbers, not just responsibilities
Post regularly: Share insights, lessons learned, industry trends 2-3x per week
Engage authentically: Comment thoughtfully on others' posts in your industry
Connect strategically: Add people in your industry with personalized notes

sections.content: Personal branding isn't about becoming an influencer—it's about being known by the right people. You don't need 100,000 followers. You need 100-1,000 people in your industry who know your name, respect your work, and think of you when opportunities arise. Quality of network beats quantity.

sections.title: Personal Branding Don'ts
items: Don't be inauthentic: Playing a character exhausts you and people detect it
Don't overshare personal life: Some personal is good, but maintain professional boundaries
Don't just consume: Passive scrolling doesn't build brand, creating and engaging does
Don't copy others' voice: Learn from successful people but develop your authentic style
Don't wait for perfection: Start sharing insights now, improve as you go

quiz.question: What is personal branding?
options: Having a large social media following
Your professional reputation and what people think when they hear your name
quiz.explanation: Personal brand is your professional reputation—the perception people have of your expertise, reliability, and value.

quiz.question: What's more valuable than having 100,000 followers?
options: Being known by 100-1,000 people in your industry who respect your work
quiz.explanation: Quality beats quantity in networking. Being known by the right people in your industry is more valuable than large but irrelevant followings.

sections.content: Your resume has 6-10 seconds to capture attention before it's rejected or moved forward. Hiring managers and recruiters scan for relevant keywords, quantified achievements, and clear value proposition. A mediocre resume prevents great candidates from getting interviews, while an optimized resume opens doors. The goal isn't creative writing—it's passing screening filters and proving value quickly.

sections.title: Resume Structure
items: Header: Name, title, phone, email, LinkedIn, portfolio/GitHub if relevant (no address needed)
Summary (optional): 2-3 sentences highlighting years of experience, specialization, key value proposition
Experience: Reverse chronological, bullet points showing impact with metrics
Skills: List technical skills, tools, certifications relevant to target role
Education: Degree, school, graduation year (GPA only if recent grad and 3.5+)
Length: 1 page for <10 years experience, 2 pages for 10+ years

sections.content: The magic is in the bullet points. Avoid responsibility descriptions ('Managed social media accounts'). Focus on achievements with metrics ('Grew Instagram following from 5K to 50K in 6 months, increasing engagement rate from 2% to 8%'). Every bullet should answer: What did you do? What was the impact? What were the numbers?

sections.title: Bullet Point Formula
items: Action verb + what you did + quantified result
Bad: 'Responsible for customer service'
Good: 'Resolved 50+ customer inquiries daily, maintaining 4.8/5 satisfaction rating'
Bad: 'Managed projects'
Good: 'Led 5 cross-functional projects worth $2M, delivering all on-time and 15% under budget'
Numbers > words: Use percentages, dollar amounts, time savings, growth rates

sections.title: ATS (Applicant Tracking System) Optimization
items: Use keywords from job description: ATS scans for specific skills and experience
Avoid tables, graphics, headers/footers: Can confuse ATS parsing
Use standard section headers: 'Work Experience' not 'My Professional Journey'
Spell out acronyms once: 'Search Engine Optimization (SEO)' then use 'SEO'
Save as .docx or PDF: Most ATS handle these formats best
Test with jobscan.co: Free tool shows how well your resume matches job descriptions

sections.content: Tailor your resume for each application. This doesn't mean rewriting everything—maintain a master resume with all accomplishments, then customize by emphasizing relevant skills and experiences for each role. A tailored resume showing exactly what they need beats a generic resume showing everything you've done.

sections.title: Common Resume Mistakes
items: Objective statement: Waste of space, everyone wants 'a challenging role with growth opportunity'
Typos and grammar errors: Instant rejection, get multiple people to review
Unprofessional email: Use firstname.lastname@gmail.com, not partygirl2000@hotmail.com
Gaps without explanation: Address employment gaps briefly (freelancing, education, family care)
Irrelevant information: Ancient jobs, hobbies, physical characteristics
Lying or exaggerating: Always gets discovered, permanently damages reputation

quiz.question: What's the most important element of resume bullet points?
quiz.explanation: Quantified achievements with metrics (numbers, percentages, dollar amounts) show concrete impact and prove your value.

quiz.question: How long should your resume be if you have 7 years of experience?
quiz.explanation: For under 10 years of experience, keep resumes to 1 page. Focus on most relevant and impactful achievements.

quiz.question: What is an ATS?
options: Applicant Tracking System that scans resumes for keywords
quiz.explanation: ATS (Applicant Tracking System) is software that scans and filters resumes based on keywords and qualifications before humans review them.

sections.content: Interviewing is a skill that dramatically improves with preparation and practice. Great candidates fail interviews through poor preparation; average candidates succeed with excellent interviewing skills. Interviews aren't about honestly answering questions—they're about strategically presenting yourself as the solution to the employer's problems. Master this and you'll consistently land offers above your perceived level.

sections.title: Pre-Interview Preparation
items: Research company: Read recent news, understand products/services, know competitors, review Glassdoor
Research interviewers: LinkedIn profiles to understand their background and interests
Prepare stories: 5-7 STAR method stories covering different competencies
Prepare questions: 3-5 thoughtful questions showing you researched the role and company
Practice delivery: Record yourself answering common questions, refine until natural
Technical prep: For technical roles, review concepts and practice problems on LeetCode, HackerRank

sections.content: The STAR method structures your answers: Situation (context), Task (challenge/goal), Action (what you did), Result (outcome with metrics). This framework keeps answers concise, focused, and impressive. Every answer should end with quantified results. 'I improved the process' is weak. 'I reduced processing time by 40%, saving the team 10 hours weekly' is powerful.

sections.title: Common Interview Questions
items: Tell me about yourself: 60-second pitch highlighting relevant experience, not life story
Why this company/role?: Show you researched, connect to your career goals, express genuine interest
Greatest weakness: Real weakness + what you're doing to improve, avoid humble brags
Describe a challenge: Use STAR method, emphasize problem-solving and results
Where do you see yourself in 5 years?: Show ambition aligned with company, avoid 'your job'
Why should we hire you?: Connect your unique skills to their specific needs

sections.title: Interview Performance Tips
items: First impression: Business appropriate dress, arrive 10 min early (but not earlier), firm handshake, smile
Energy level: Match interviewer's energy plus 10%, show enthusiasm without seeming desperate
Listen actively: Don't interrupt, take brief notes, pause before answering to show thoughtfulness
Ask clarifying questions: Shows analytical thinking, buys time to formulate better answers
Close strong: Reiterate interest, ask about next steps, thank them for their time
Follow up: Send thank-you email within 24 hours, reference specific conversation points

sections.content: Behavioral interviews assess past behavior predicting future performance. Technical interviews test knowledge and problem-solving under pressure. Case interviews evaluate analytical thinking. Phone screens filter out weak candidates. Final round interviews validate fit and close the deal. Each type requires different preparation strategies but all reward practice.

sections.title: Interview Mistakes to Avoid
items: Talking too much: Answer in 1-2 minutes, not 10-minute monologues
Badmouthing previous employers: Always frame departures positively (growth, new challenges)
Focusing on what you want: Frame answers around value you provide, not what you need
Not preparing questions: Asking nothing signals disinterest
Lying about skills: You'll be exposed and waste everyone's time
Discussing salary too early: Wait for offer before negotiating, exception if they demand number

sections.title: Your Questions to Ask
items: What does success look like in this role in first 90 days?
What are the biggest challenges facing the team/department?
How would you describe the company/team culture?
What opportunities for growth and development exist?
What do you enjoy most about working here? (Personal connection)
Avoid: Questions about salary, benefits, time off in early rounds

quiz.question: What is the STAR method?
options: Structure for answering questions: Situation, Task, Action, Result
quiz.explanation: STAR method structures answers by describing Situation, Task, Action taken, and Result achieved—providing complete, impressive responses.

quiz.question: When should you send a thank-you email after an interview?
options: Only if you get the job
quiz.explanation: Send thank-you emails within 24 hours while you're still fresh in interviewers' minds, showing professionalism and continued interest.

quiz.question: How should you answer 'What is your greatest weakness?'
options: Give a strength disguised as weakness ('I work too hard')
Share real weakness and what you're doing to improve it
quiz.explanation: Show self-awareness by sharing a real but not disqualifying weakness, plus specific steps you're taking to improve. Demonstrates growth mindset.

sections.content: Negotiating your salary is the highest-ROI activity you'll ever perform. A single successful negotiation can earn you $5,000-20,000+ more annually, which compounds over your career. Yet most people accept first offers without negotiating, leaving hundreds of thousands on the table over a lifetime. Companies expect negotiation—not negotiating signals you undervalue yourself.

sections.title: Pre-Negotiation Preparation
items: Research market rates: Use Levels.fyi, Glassdoor, PayScale, industry salary surveys for your role/location
Know your value: Document achievements, skills, certifications that justify higher compensation
Determine your range: Minimum acceptable, target salary, aspirational number
Consider total compensation: Base, bonus, equity, benefits, work-life balance, growth opportunities
Gather competing offers: Multiple offers provide immense negotiating leverage
Practice delivery: Role-play negotiation conversations until comfortable

sections.content: Timing is critical. Never discuss salary until you have an offer. When asked about salary expectations early, deflect with 'I'd like to learn more about the role first' or 'I'm sure we can find a fair number once we determine fit.' The person who mentions numbers first typically loses. Make them commit first.

sections.title: Negotiation Tactics
items: Anchor high: If forced to name number, start at top of market range—they'll negotiate down
Never accept first offer: Always counter, even if offer seems good. Room exists.
Justify with data: 'Based on market research for this role and my X years experience, I was expecting $Y'
Use silence: After stating your number, stay quiet. Let them respond first.
Trade-offs: If they can't move on salary, negotiate bonus, equity, vacation, remote work, title
Get it in writing: Verbal agreements mean nothing, confirm all terms in offer letter

sections.title: Negotiation Scripts
items: First offer response: 'Thank you for the offer. I'm excited about the role. Based on my research and experience, I was expecting closer to $X. Is there flexibility?'
If they say no: 'I understand the salary constraints. Can we discuss signing bonus, equity, or additional vacation days?'
Multiple offers: 'I have another offer at $X, but I prefer your company. Can you match?'
Current salary question: 'I'd prefer to focus on the value I'll bring to this role rather than my current compensation'
Final counteroffer: 'I appreciate you working with me. If you can reach $X, I'm ready to accept today'

sections.content: Women and minorities statistically negotiate less often and less aggressively, contributing to pay gaps. If you're uncomfortable advocating for yourself, reframe it: you're not being difficult, you're establishing fair value. Companies profit when employees don't negotiate. Don't subsidize their profits by underselling yourself.

sections.title: Negotiation Mistakes
items: Accepting first offer: Leaves $5k-20k+ on table, companies expect negotiation
Revealing current salary: Anchors negotiation to past, not future value
Negotiating from desperation: Need money ≠ negotiate poorly, wait for strong position if possible
Multiple rounds without progress: If 2-3 counters don't move them, either accept or walk
Burning bridges: Stay professional even if rejecting, industry is small
Bluffing about other offers: Never lie, always gets discovered

sections.title: Beyond Base Salary
items: Signing bonus: One-time payment, easier for companies than ongoing salary increases
Performance bonus: 10-30% of salary for hitting targets
Equity: Stock options or RSUs, can be worth more than salary at startups/tech companies
Benefits: Health insurance, 401k match, education reimbursement
Work arrangements: Remote work, flexible hours, extra vacation days
Review timeline: Negotiate earlier performance review for potential raise

quiz.question: When should you discuss salary expectations?
options: Only after receiving a formal offer
When the recruiter first contacts you
quiz.explanation: Wait until you have a formal offer before discussing specific numbers. This gives you maximum leverage and ensures they're committed to hiring you.

quiz.question: Should you always negotiate even if the first offer seems good?
options: No, you might lose the offer
Yes, there's almost always room to negotiate
Only if you have other offers
quiz.explanation: Always negotiate. Companies expect it, build room into offers, and won't rescind offers for reasonable negotiation. You leave money on table by not asking.

quiz.question: If they can't increase base salary, what else can you negotiate?
options: Nothing, salary is all that matters
Signing bonus, equity, vacation, remote work, title
quiz.explanation: Total compensation includes many elements beyond base salary. Negotiate signing bonus, equity, benefits, work arrangements, and review timeline.
